title: Sentiment Analysis
contents: A nice introduction for methodology and algos in the field for non-practitioners. Topics like aspect mining and detecting fake reviews are particularly interesting.

Given the difficulty of the topic it is not feasible to build a usable application with this book alone. Nevertheless such background knowledge is nice as sentiment analysis apps might improve significantly in near future.

title: Changing Mind
contents: An introduction to cognitive and developmental psychology and neuroscience, good for first reading in this field. Overall it is not well focused, a bit wordy and written for casual readers. This could be much better if volume could shrink by half.
Key takeaway is to always try new things in life, keep healthy social network (with young people) and exercise.

title: Solved
contents: It is a fine casual reading. Key takeaways are the country comparison table near the end and that immigrants become less attractive to host countries as they age, while temp residents are always welcome as they contribute consumption without tapping public resources.

The book would be more interesting to address from policymaker perspective and examine why policymakers do not adopt the "better" policies. Many of objectives in the book (higher growth, less inequality, democracy) might be means rather than end goals in policymaker eyes, depending on the country.

title: Morgan Stanley Research
contents: If you have access to Morgan Stanley Research welcome to take a look at my works there, with the best ones on Global EM Strategist.

title: Data Science
contents: Surprisingly comprehensive and insight book on statistical learning theory. Good for refreshing memory but could be a bit challenging for first time readers.

title: State of Science
contents: General science book with latest development in particular on gravitational wave, CRISPR gene editing and science funding.

title: Die with Zero
contents: To admit this book is not for people enjoying career success...
But if you are in a bottleneck at work like me, try a read and you will come out happier and less anxious. A better mood will help everything in your life then~

title: 医学通识讲义
contents: I read this for some common knowledge in medical science, stressing that self-repair of the body is the ultimate way.

title: Economics of Money
contents: A good introduction into macro economic practices and central banking in modern world. I read this in undergrad and have recalled knowledge from this many times since then.

title: Elements of Statistical Learning
contents: Needless to say this is an entry book for many statistical learning practitioners... Purely about the algos.
The thinner An Introduction to Statistical Learning is better if you are looking for a first time read in this field.

title: Applied Mathematics
contents: This covers most concepts encountered in financial data science. Should read another book for modern linear algebra.
The book contains interesting use cases in physics, finance and numerical modelling.

title: Financial Machine Learning
contents: This book is about financial ML practices instead of algos. Much about data cleaning, feature selection and performance evaluation.
The features part a bit focusing on microstructure but still worth reading for lower-frequency players.

title: Feature Engineering
contents: Great practical guide for feature engineering in scikit-learn, such as Pipelines.
It is direct on the implementation level, should read algos and some practition guide before reading this.

title: VBA and Macros
contents: A nice intro on VBA. I have not used VBA for years and after I read this the use cases are still limited in work.
VBA is in a middle-of-nowhere given Excel to do one-off work and Pythhon to handle systematic, repetitive processing...

title: Digital Currency
contents: The central bank digital currency (CBDC) could collect massive private data for the central bank which could be useful for various purposes, including targeted rather than broad-based policy action.
However, central banks using targeted subsidy ("helicopter money") might blur the lines between monetary and fiscal policy.
CBDC could become a safer alternative to bank deposits that lead to narrow banking or increased moral hazard in banks, given much larger lending needed from central bank to commercial banks.

Nevertheless, the informational and social benefits (to squeeze out private coins and cash to better track economic activities) of CBDC are too large to ignore, and many Asia central banks, leading by PBOC, started initiatives to launch CBDC.
It could be a game changer in a low-rate environment where traditional monetary policy space has been limited.

title: Effective Python
contents: The assignment operator is almost the only thing new for me but it is available only in v3.8. This book has a short but nice coverage on parallelism.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning
contents: Reinforcement Learning would be ideal for trading execution strategy where we have a market impact model.

However in most backtesting nowadays investor trades are assumed not impacting market movement, which is why we could do backtesting. In this scenario conventional supervised learning seems superior as historical data would be very limited for reinforcement learning purpose.

title: Angular and Typescript
contents: This book inspired me to build this website... The book is fine but not surprising that I learned most of Angular by coding rather than reading!

description: Hedge Fund Portfolio Strategy Based on Performance Persistence and Portfolio Theory.
title: Hedge Fund Portfolio Strategy
contents: This paper discussed systematic methods to construct funds of funds (FOF) products investing in Chinese hedge funds, with low risk, high return and high Sharpe Ratio, or other ideal characteristics required by investors. Using performance data of more than 600 hedge funds, we applied standard portfolio theory to design portfolios with optimized risk and return features. Tradable FOF products with low risk, high return and high Sharpe Ratio were described in detail, with outstanding performances confirmed by systematic backtest and robust tests. Collectively, our results offer a sound investing product based on Chinese hedge fund performance, and are valuable both as an independent product and as a major component in a more comprehensive portfolio.
It was my master degree thesis and practiced portfolio theory along with statistical testing.

title: Quant Research Ideas
contents: This paper discussed three in-detail quantitative trading ideas for equity markets in China and Japan. First idea discusses the emerging 50 ETF option markets in China and the feasibility of a covered call strategy. Second idea evaluates the opportunities implied by the ETF purchase program of Bank of Japan. Third idea demonstrates the predicting effectiveness of Chinese short selling and margin buying data with feature selection. Limitations and concerns for each idea is discussed separately. With a valuation model established in the first section, we are able to value each trading idea at 1.5M, 0.46M and 0.33M USD respectively, based on derived estimates of strategy performances and investment characteristics.
It practiced feature engineering and single name equity alpha mostly following Advances in Financial Machine Learning and Feature Engineering.

title: About Me
contents: I’ve been a professional quantitative researcher for five years now, with most of that time spent at Morgan Stanley. In my earlier years I was building the algorithmic trading strategies (pretty interesting stuff) and that was all Java. These days at work I am looking into macro strategies in Asia with a quantamental approach, using Python as a handy tool.
I’ve spent the last decade moving between Shanghai, New York, and Hong Kong. I enjoy reading about statistics, computer science, finance and detective novels.
If you’d like to get in touch about anything please don’t hesitate to drop me an email.
